dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, security tokens. They're like, totally the reason crypto's finally, you know, hitting the mainstream, right? Everyone's buying into them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, security tokens. They're like, totally the reason crypto's finally, you know, hitting the mainstream, right? Everyone's buying into them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The market for security tokens, or traditional securities turned into digital assets, is quiet The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand. Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto. Conferences sprung up entirely focused on security tokens. But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, actually, A, not quite. Not yet, anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, actually, A, not quite. Not yet, anyway.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: What? But, like, I thought they were supposed to be the next big thing, the "mega-trend"?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What? But, like, I thought they were supposed to be the next big thing, the mega-trend?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that was the hype. But the market for them, it’s really, um, quiet right now. Like, super quiet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that was the hype. But the market for them, it's really, um, quiet right now. Like, super quiet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The market for security tokens, or traditional securities turned into digital assets, is quiet

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But isn't the idea, like, super smart? Turning regular stuff into digital assets?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But isn't the idea, like, super smart? Turning regular stuff into digital assets?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The idea makes sense on paper. Making private investments more portable, more liquid. But in reality, progress has, uh, stalled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The idea makes sense on paper. Making private investments more portable, more liquid. But in reality, progress has, uh, stalled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand. ... But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Stalled? How can it stall? Aren't there, like, tons of them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Stalled? How can it stall? Aren't there, like, tons of them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: There are over a hundred security tokens created, sure. But they’re not liquid. Trading volume is, like, tiny. We're talking less than a million dollars a day on, uh, most exchanges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: There are over a hundred security tokens created, sure. But they're not liquid. Trading volume is, like, tiny. We're talking less than a million dollars a day on, uh, most exchanges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More than 100 security tokens have been created, according to Polymath, a startup that helps companies mint coins. But theyre not liquid. In the U.S., just two exchanges exist where these assets trade, and volume is tiny. Openfinance trades only four assets with daily transactions of less than $1 million a day, we estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh. So, what's the deal then? Is it, like, the tech? Is it too hard to do?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh. So, what's the deal then? Is it, like, the tech? Is it too hard to do?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not really the tech. A lot of it comes down to, um, regulation. Big time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not really the tech. A lot of it comes down to, um, regulation. Big time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many of the barriers to adoption are regulation-related.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Regulation? Like, the SEC? Are they just dragging their feet on this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Regulation? Like, the S E C? Are they just dragging their feet on this?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One crypto CEO says the SEC is dragging its feet on evaluating and granting new ATS applications to digital asset companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. For a company to set up a trading venue for these, they need to register as a broker-dealer, get an exchange license... it's a long, expensive process. And the SEC, uh, seems to have internal disagreements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. For a company to set up a trading venue for these, they need to register as a broker-dealer, get an exchange license... it's a long, expensive process. And the S E C, uh, seems to have internal disagreements.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For U.S. companies to build a trading venue for security tokens, they must register as a broker-dealer with the SEC and get a license for either an exchange or an alternative trading system (ATS), which requires a long and costly process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And I thought these were supposed to be, like, global investments? Easy to trade anywhere?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And I thought these were supposed to be, like, global investments? Easy to trade anywhere?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: In theory, yeah. A "global IPO." But, um, all the participating nations would need to agree on a common framework. And that's, like, a huge hurdle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: In theory, yeah. A global I P O. But, um, all the participating nations would need to agree on a common framework. And that's, like, a huge hurdle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In theory, security tokens could allow for a global IPO, says Olga Feldmeier, founder and CEO of Swiss security token exchange Smart Valor. ... But all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, just making a paper security digital doesn't magically make it, uh, popular?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, just making a paper security digital doesn't magically make it, uh, popular?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. People underestimated the difficulty of generating investor demand. Yelling "token" isn't a substitute for, you know, a good investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. People underestimated the difficulty of generating investor demand. Yelling token isn't a substitute for, you know, a good investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many people had underestimated the difficulty of generating investor demand for securities. ... Josh Stein, CEO of San Francisco security token platform Harbor, agrees. People have realized that yelling the word token is not a substitute for a good investment or distribution channels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, is it just, like, dead in the water then? All that hype for nothing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, is it just, like, dead in the water then? All that hype for nothing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not dead. The long-term benefits, like faster settlement, are still compelling. But the short-term outlook? Pretty dim. We're talking five to ten years for the infrastructure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not dead. The long-term benefits, like faster settlement, are still compelling. But the short-term outlook? Pretty dim. We're talking five to ten years for the infrastructure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The long-term benefits of security tokens remain compelling. Fred Schebesta, founder of Australian comparison site Finder and cofounder of crypto exchange HiveEx, says that faster settlement for banking transactions is the most important feature... The short-term outlook seems dim. ... Smart Valors Olga Feldmeier thinks it will take five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure necessary for security tokens to trade across nearly every country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Man. So it's all just waiting on, uh, regulators to get their act together?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man. So it's all just waiting on, uh, regulators to get their act together?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much, yeah.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much, yeah.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One thing is for sure: if adoption is contingent on regulators making a move, investors will be waiting longer than theyd like.
